column3: Yabuqa watches the flames of the fire, a wistful expression upon his face.
Say, friend, might you do me a favor?

Not too far to the southeast of here are the decimated ruins of Kahkol Iloh. I ask that you go there and <UIForeground>F201F4</UIForeground><UIGlow>F201F5</UIGlow>pray<UIGlow>01</UIGlow><UIForeground>01</UIForeground> for the souls of my deceased parents and sister.
<sigh> It is not a sentiment any of the other Buduga would understand, which is why I need for you to go in my stead.

Please, make your way to Kahkol Iloh and send your <UIForeground>F201F4</UIForeground><UIGlow>F201F5</UIGlow>prayers<UIGlow>01</UIGlow><UIForeground>01</UIForeground> to my parents and sister. Mayhap through you, they will receive mine, as well.

I appreciate you entertaining such an...odd request. Many of the other Budugan warriors will think me soft for it, but I always feel the need to send someone out to my old village at this time of year to pray for them.
Ah─it seems I neglected to tell you that I am originally from Kahkol Iloh. When I was a child, the Buduga came and pillaged our settlement. My family offered me up to them as tribute.
For the longest time I resented them. I eventually came to learn, however, that shortly after I left, a deadly epidemic swept through my old home and killed everyone who had been left behind.
I suspect my parents knew what was to come and sent me away to protect me. <sigh> I have years of making up to do for the hatred I harbored in my heart toward them.

As a member of the Buduga it is difficult for me to find opportunities to visit Kahkol Iloh and offer them my prayers. That is why I ask travelers passing through to lend me their assistance. You have my sincerest gratitude, friend.
